contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Climbing fish | image = AnabasScandens.png | image_caption = ''[[Anabas testudineus]]'' | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Actinopterygii]] | ordo = [[Perciformes]] | subordo = [[Anabantoidei]] | familia = '''Anabantidae''' | familia_authority = [[Charles Lucien Bonaparte|Bonaparte]], 1831 | subdivision_ranks = Genera<ref>{{FishBase family | family = Anabantidae| month = December | year = 2012}}</ref> | subdivision = ''[[Anabas]]''<br/> ''[[Ctenopoma]]''<br/> ''[[Microctenopoma]]''<br/> ''[[Sandelia]]'' }} The '''Anabantidae''' are a [[family (biology)|family]] of [[perciform]] [[fish]] commonly called the '''climbing gouramies''' or '''climbing perches'''. As [[Anabantoidei|labyrinth fishes]], they possess a [[labyrinth organ]], a structure in the fish's head which allows it to breathe atmospheric [[oxygen]]. Fish of this family are commonly seen gulping at air at the surface of the water. The air is held in a structure called the supra-branchial chamber, where oxygen diffuses into the bloodstream via the respiratory epithelium covering the labyrinth organ. [[Image:AnabasLyd.jpg|thumb|left|Climbing perch (''Anabas testudineus'') on land]] Of the four genera, ''[[Anabas]]'' is found from [[South Asia]] (they are called chemballi (Malayalam: ചെമ്പല്ലി) in [[Kerala]], India), east to China and [[Southeast Asia]]. The remaining three genera are all restricted to Africa. They are primarily a [[Fresh water|freshwater]] fish and only very rarely found in [[brackish]] water. An egg-layer, they typically guard their [[Egg (biology)|eggs]] and young. Climbing gouramis are so named due to their ability to "climb" out of water and "walk" short distances. Their method of terrestrial locomotion uses the gill plates as supports and the fish pushes itself using the fins and tail. == References == {{reflist}} *{{ITIS |id=172583 |taxon=Anabantidae |accessdate=April 28, 2004}} [[Category:Anabantidae|*]] [[Category:Fish of Southeast Asia]] [[Category:Fish of Thailand]] [[Category:Amphibious fish]]
